results.title: Heaven, hell and Eldorado
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon”.
The Amazonian jungle, the largest in the world, covers almost half of South America. For the white man the jungle is a mysterious realm, an El Dorado, that has attracted adventurers and missionaries in search of wealth and souls, ever since the time of Columbus. Jack Pizzey travels through three countries to assess the impact of loggers, gold miners, ranchers, road builders and missionaries on both the Amazonian jungle and the Indians who inhabit it. The question remains, is Western civilisation turning this Eden into Hell?

results.title: Kings for a day
results.creator_credit: Clive Fleury, Geoffrey Barnes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon”.
Jack Pizzey is in Brazil the week before Carnaval, Rio’s fantastic explosion of glittering, sexy extravagance, a celebration where even the poor blacks of the fovellas (shanty towns) can be “Kings for a Day”. Preparations for Carnaval are top secret and intense as rival teams vie for the top prize as champions of Carnaval. Pizzey himself, bedecked in sequins and lurex, is able to take part in the all-night climax of this unique festival.

results.title: Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon
results.creator_credit: Clive Fleury, Geoffrey Barnes and ABC
results.brief_description: In 1984, writer and presenter, Jack Pizzey, visited eight South American countries to assess the current political and social climate and the extent of the legacy left by Spanish and Portuguese invaders who came in search of gold (Sweat of the sun), silver (tears of the moon) and Indian souls.

results.title: Proper winter clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Skiers, hikers and other winter outdoor people learn quickly that it is not how much you have on but what you wear and how you wear it. this film provides the necessary clues to keeping you warm during outdoor travel in winter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions

results.title: Proper summer bush clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Hugh Moreland and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Two boys head off on a fishing trip, one wearing correct clothing, and the other, ordinary light summer weight slacks and shirt. As the film progresses, the viewer sees that proper clothing is essential to one’s comfort and well-being when camping out.

results.title: The Leopard that changed its spots
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival Anglia Wildlife Series”.
David Niven narrates the remarkable story of three year-old Harriet, a female leopard and her relationship with conservationist Billy Arjan Singh, who had raised her from a cub. Returning to the wild of her own accord, Harriet mates with a wild leopard but rears her two cubs in a tree house, built for her by Billy at Tiger Haven, until she moves them back to the jungle after a few weeks. A moving testament to a beautiful and fascinating creature whose natural habitat is being eroded by a land-hungry human population.

results.title: Last kingdom of the elephant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival Anglia Wildlife Series”.
Narrated by Orson Welles this is a description of the Luangwa Valley in Zambia. This is one of the last remaining unspoiled wildlife sanctuaries left in Africa where wild animals still exist in the variety and quantity of the days before the white man and the gun with no poaching, hunting, tourism or exploitation. The reserve contains on of the greatest concentrations of large animals in Africa including an estimated 100,000 elephants, 20,000 each of hippos and crocodiles, as well as great numbers of antelope, giraffe and of course, lions. The valley is also the last stronghold of the notorious Black Rhino said to number at least 4,000. Shot over two years this documentary records the harsh and varied lifestyle of the valley’s inhabitants through the seasons. See just how vicious a hippo can be, and how quarrelsome lions really are! The film also sounds a warning about the future of the elephants living in this untouched paradise. They have thrived being unmolested by humans but are in danger of eating themselves into a decline.

results.title: Wolf: the spanish outlaw
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival Anglia Wildlife Series”.
Hywel Bennett narrates this documentary about the wolves who inhabit remote regions of Spain and their fight for survival in the face of hostility from Spanish villagers, whose sheep they kill for food. Once the most widely distributed mammal in Europe, man’s hatred of these animals has led to their destruction in nearly all countries, and unless the regional governments of Spain provide a solution the wolf may once again be subject to indiscriminate hunting and poisoning.

results.title: Balloon safari = Safari by balloon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival Anglia Wildlife Series”.
Shows cameraman, Alan Root, and his wife Jean’s experiences with their own hot air balloon over Kenya. As they were learning how to operate it, forced landings in lakes, thick bush and herds of animals became almost daily occurrences. The Root’s balloon adventures took them across some of the most spectacular places in Africa, but they were drawn towards Mount Kilimanjaro, in Tanzania, where they realised their ambition to fly by balloon above its snow-capped peak.
